subject: Re: [junit] should new Integer(1) equal new Long(1)
msgSnippet: ... I think it makes the most sense to behave consistently with equals(), rather than try to compensate for its behavior. It s probably poor design to compare

David Saff wrote:

> Kent and I continue to try to fine-tune equality to produce the least
> surprise, and continue to wonder if well enough should have been left
> alone. In 4.3, we introduced some run-time math magic to make up for
> the lack of type-expansion once we had removed most of the primitive
> type assertEquals methods. Thus, it became the case, somewhat
> accidentally, that this would pass:
> 
> assertEquals(new Integer(1), new Long(1)); // A
> 
> However, it simultaneously became the case that this would also pass:
> 
> assertEquals(new BigDecimal("1.0"), new BigDecimal("1.1")); // B
> 
> Line B should certainly fail. The simplest thing to do is to remove
> our math magic, introduce assertEquals(long, long), etc, and let
> numerical classes define their own equality. This means that line A
> will now fail, since that's how Integer.equals() is defined. This is
> a small behavior change, but a "regression" of sorts.
> 
> If anyone believes this is a damaging decision, please let me know.

I think it makes the most sense to behave consistently with equals(), 
rather than try to compensate for its behavior. It's probably poor 
design to compare Integer objects with Long objects, anyway.
